hints.label: def-episode-relabeling-group-rigorous
hints.title: Episode Relabeling Gauge Group
hints.content:
668: :label: def-episode-relabeling-group-rigorous
669: 
670: Let $\mathcal{E} = \\{e_1, \ldots, e_{|\mathcal{E}|}\\}$ be the set of episodes in the Fractal Set. The **episode relabeling group** is:
671: 
672: $$
673: G_{\text{epi}} = S_{|\mathcal{E}|}
674: $$
675: 
676: the symmetric group on $|\mathcal{E}|$ elements.
677: 
678: **Gauge transformation:** A permutation $\sigma \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$ acts on the Fractal Set by:
679: 
680: $$
681: \sigma: e_i \mapsto e_{\sigma(i)}
682: $$
683: 
684: relabeling all episodes.
685: 
686: **Physical equivalence:** Two Fractal Sets $\mathcal{F}$ and $\mathcal{F}'$ are **physically equivalent** if $\mathcal{F}' = \sigma \cdot \mathcal{F}$ for some $\sigma \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$.
hints.raw_directive:
665: The old documentation develops a **discrete gauge theory** where the gauge group is the **permutation group of episodes**, not a continuous Lie group.

hints.label: thm-discrete-permutation-invariance-rigorous
hints.title: Discrete Permutation Invariance
hints.content:
692: :label: thm-discrete-permutation-invariance-rigorous
693: 
694: The probability distribution over Fractal Sets is **invariant** under episode relabeling:
695: 
696: $$
697: \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{F}) = \mathcal{L}(\sigma \cdot \mathcal{F}) \quad \forall \sigma \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}
698: $$
699: 
700: where $\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{F})$ denotes the law of the random Fractal Set.
701: 
702: **Proof:** Episodes are labeled arbitrarily during simulation. The underlying stochastic process treats all episodes symmetrically - labels are bookkeeping, not physical.
703: 
704: **Consequence:** All **gauge-invariant observables** must be symmetric functions of episodes:
705: 
706: $$
707: O(\sigma \cdot \mathcal{F}) = O(\mathcal{F}) \quad \forall \sigma \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}
708: $$

hints.label: def-discrete-gauge-connection-rigorous
hints.title: Discrete Gauge Connection on Fractal Set
hints.content:
716: :label: def-discrete-gauge-connection-rigorous
717: 
718: The **discrete gauge connection** defines parallel transport along CST and IG edges.
719: 
720: **Gauge group:** $G_{\text{gauge}} = S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$ (episode permutations)
721: 
722: **Parallel transport operators:**
723: 
724: 1. **CST edges** (timelike, causal):
725:    $$\mathcal{T}^{\text{CST}}(e_i^t \to e_i^{t+1}) = \text{id} \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$$
726: 
727:    **Interpretation:** Episode index is **preserved** along temporal evolution (same walker)
728: 
729: 2. **IG edges** (spacelike, non-causal):
730:    $$\mathcal{T}^{\text{IG}}(e_i \to e_j) = (i \, j) \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$$
731: 
732:    **Interpretation:** IG edge represents **exchange/correlation** between episodes $i$ and $j$, encoded as transposition
733: 
734: **Path-ordered product:** For a path $\gamma = (e_1 \to e_2 \to \cdots \to e_n)$:
735: 
736: $$
737: \mathcal{T}(\gamma) = \mathcal{T}(e_{n-1} \to e_n) \circ \cdots \circ \mathcal{T}(e_1 \to e_2) \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}
738: $$
hints.raw_directive:
713: ### 3.2. Discrete Parallel Transport and Connection
714: 
715: :::{prf:definition} Discrete Gauge Connection on Fractal Set
716: :label: def-discrete-gauge-connection-rigorous
717: 
718: The **discrete gauge connection** defines parallel transport along CST and IG edges.
719: 
720: **Gauge group:** $G_{\text{gauge}} = S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$ (episode permutations)
721: 
722: **Parallel transport operators:**
723: 
724: 1. **CST edges** (timelike, causal):
725:    $$\mathcal{T}^{\text{CST}}(e_i^t \to e_i^{t+1}) = \text{id} \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$$
726: 
727:    **Interpretation:** Episode index is **preserved** along temporal evolution (same walker)
728: 
729: 2. **IG edges** (spacelike, non-causal):
730:    $$\mathcal{T}^{\text{IG}}(e_i \to e_j) = (i \, j) \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}$$
731: 
732:    **Interpretation:** IG edge represents **exchange/correlation** between episodes $i$ and $j$, encoded as transposition
733: 
734: **Path-ordered product:** For a path $\gamma = (e_1 \to e_2 \to \cdots \to e_n)$:
735: 
736: $$
737: \mathcal{T}(\gamma) = \mathcal{T}(e_{n-1} \to e_n) \circ \cdots \circ \mathcal{T}(e_1 \to e_2) \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}
738: $$

hints.label: thm-connection-to-braid-holonomy-rigorous
hints.title: Connection to Braid Holonomy
hints.content:
744: :label: thm-connection-to-braid-holonomy-rigorous
745: 
746: The discrete gauge connection on the Fractal Set is **compatible** with the braid group holonomy from Chapter 12.
747: 
748: Specifically, for a closed path $\gamma$ in the Fractal Set, the discrete holonomy:
749: 
750: $$
751: \text{Hol}_{\mathcal{F}}(\gamma) = \mathcal{T}(\gamma) \in S_{|\mathcal{E}|}
752: $$
753: 
754: agrees with the braid holonomy projected to $S_N$ via the natural homomorphism $\rho: B_N \to S_N$.
755: 
756: **Consequence:** The Fractal Set discrete gauge structure is the **lattice regularization** of the continuous braid gauge theory.

hints.label: def-discrete-curvature-rigorous
hints.title: Discrete Curvature Functional
hints.content:
764: :label: def-discrete-curvature-rigorous
765: 
766: For a closed loop (plaquette) $P$ in the Fractal Set, define the **discrete curvature** as:
767: 
768: $$
769: \kappa(P) = \begin{cases}
770: 0 & \text{if } \text{Hol}(P) = \text{id} \\
771: 1 & \text{if } \text{Hol}(P) \neq \text{id}
772: \end{cases}
773: $$
774: 
775: **Interpretation:** The loop has non-trivial holonomy if parallel transport around it produces a non-identity permutation.
hints.raw_directive:
761: ### 3.3. Wilson Loops and Holonomy Observables
762: 
763: :::{prf:definition} Discrete Curvature Functional
764: :label: def-discrete-curvature-rigorous
765: 
766: For a closed loop (plaquette) $P$ in the Fractal Set, define the **discrete curvature** as:
767: 
768: $$
769: \kappa(P) = \begin{cases}
770: 0 & \text{if } \text{Hol}(P) = \text{id} \\
771: 1 & \text{if } \text{Hol}(P) \neq \text{id}
772: \end{cases}
773: $$
774: 
775: **Interpretation:** The loop has non-trivial holonomy if parallel transport around it produces a non-identity permutation.

hints.label: thm-ig-fundamental-cycles-rigorous
hints.title: IG Edges Close Fundamental Cycles
hints.content:
781: :label: thm-ig-fundamental-cycles-rigorous
782: 
783: If the CST is a **tree** (single root, no cycles), then each IG edge $(e_i, e_j)$ closes **exactly one fundamental cycle**:
784: 
785: $$
786: C_{ij} = \text{CST path from root to } e_i + (e_i \to e_j)_{\text{IG}} + \text{CST path from } e_j \text{ back to root}
787: $$
788: 
789: **Consequence:** The number of independent Wilson loops equals the number of IG edges.
790: 
791: **Graph theory:** This is the standard result that in a tree with $V$ vertices and $E_{\text{tree}} = V-1$ edges, adding $E_{\text{IG}}$ edges creates $E_{\text{IG}}$ independent cycles (first Betti number).
